Award.AwardTitle: Interactions between Long Ocean Waves and Muddy Sea Floor
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: On the continental shelf and in the coastal zone, wind waves interact with sea floor and a number of dynamic processes take place. If the sea floor is composed of sediments, a variety of dissipation mechanisms associated with the sediment rheology play important roles in enhancing wave damping and in modifying wave characteristics. Under this project the investigator will conduct an integrated theoretical and experimental program to accomplish several scientific goals. First, analytical solutions for mud flows under transient wave loadings will be developed to improve our fundamental understanding of various sea bottom dissipative mechanisms and their impacts on transient long wave propagation. Second, An archive of quality detailed experimental data sets that researchers may use to test their own analytic and numerical models will be generated. Third, model-data comparisons will be performed to understand the limitations of analytical solutions and direct numerical simulation (DNS) models for mud flows under wave loadings will be developed to further explore the physical processes. A Navier-Stokes solver with different stress-strain relationships, which depend on the rheology of the fluid mud, will be developed for various wave loadings. Fourth, depth-integrated, phase-resolving wave propagation models with sea bottom dissipative mechanisms included will be developed. A case study is planned to examine the wave attenuation in the Guyana coastal system that is characterized by very thick deposits of Amazon mud.

Broader Impacts: The proposed research activities are at the interface between several field of science and engineering ¨C oceanography, fluid mechanics, and coastal engineering and will serve a bridge among them. The project will train one PhD student who will receive cutting edge training in experimental techniques, numerical methods and analytical solution techniques. Furthermore, the student will be trained in report writing and oral presentation and he/she will be encouraged to attend technical conferences and meetings. The DNS numerical models to be developed in the proposed project will be useful as research tools for many related engineering science field and can be employed after some modifications to investigate wave©\induced soil failures, debris flows and scouring around coastal structures. The Boussinesq-type wave models with the seafloor dissipative mechanisms considered, which are the main products of the project, will be useful tools for coastal engineers in various applications in the coastal regions where muddy seabeds are present. The new Boussinesq-type model can also be used to investigate the sediment transport and deposit during tsunamis. The laboratory data will be used to benchmark other numerical models under current and other development. To expedite the dissemination of what is learned during the project, we will develop and maintain a project web site, in addition to publishing manuscripts in the peer-reviewed literatures. Most of the investigator¡¯s research activities can be found on the following webpage: http://ceeserver.cee.cornell.edu/pll-group/index.htm Several upper-level undergraduate and graduate student courses at Cornell will be benefit significantly from the research project, as the laboratory measurement techniques developed in the project can be used in these courses. Currently the investigator is supervising 3 REU students supported by NSF and Engineering College fund. In the proposed project, he will carry on this tradition and encourage interested undergraduates to participate in research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In many coastal regions, including the Gulf of Mexico, seafloor is composed of various kinds of sediments.  As wind-generated waves and surges propagate over the sediment laden coastal areas a variety of dissipation mechanisms associated with the sediment rheology play important roles in enhancing wave damping and in modifying wave characteristics. To provide an accurate estimate of maximum wave heights along a coastline during a storm, it is necessary to develop a computational tool that is based on the fundamental understanding of the physical process.     

 

In this project, we carried out an integrated theoretical and experimental research program for studying the interaction between ocean waves and a muddy seafloor. More specifically, we have achieved the following scientific goals:

a.  Using the boundary layer theory, we have obtained several analytical solutions for different mud flows, including viscous mud and porous elastic mud, under transient wave loadings. Theses analytical solutions improve our fundamental understanding of various sea bottom dissipative mechanisms and their impacts on transient long wave propagation.

b.  We have also conducted several laboratory experiments in wave tank and U-tube facilities. The experimental data sets were used to check the analytical solutions. Model?data comparisons have provided a better understanding of the limitations of analytical solutions.

c.  A direct numerical simulation (DNS) model for mud flows under wave loadings was developed to further explore the physical processes. A depth?integrated, phase?resolving wave propagation model with different sea bottom dissipative mechanisms was also constructed. These numerical models have been checked with analytical solutions as well as experimental data. They are applicable for large scale field problem, such as investigate the sediment transport and deposit during tsunamis.

 

The research project has made important contribution to the scientific community by producing and archiving high quality laboratory data, which can be used to benchmark numerical models under development.

 

Several upper?level undergraduate and graduate student courses at Cornell are benefited significantly from the research project, since the laboratory measurement techniques developed in the project have been used in these courses. The research project has produced two PhDs, who have received cutting?edge training in experimental techniques, numerical methods and analytical solution. Both of them are pursuing academic career.   Three undergraduate students participated in the research project. All of them are currently PhD students in different graduate programs in coastal/ocean engineering.
